abstract.para: Use the following procedures to install a new version of &productnamereg; &productnumber;. This document gives a quick overview on how to run through a default installation of &productname; on the x86_64 architecture.

sect1.title: Welcome to &productname;
sect1.para: For more detailed installation instructions and deployment strategies, see the &productname; Documentation at .

sect2.title: Minimum System Requirements
sect2.remark: 2014-02-26 - fs: list needs to be updated, ask with Beta 7

listitem.para: Pentium* III 500 MHz or higher processor (Pentium 4 2.4 GHz or higher or any AMD64/Intel* EM64T processor recommended)
512 MB physical RAM (1 GB or more recommended)
800 x 600 display resolution (1024 x 768 or higher recommended)

sect2.title: Installing &productname;
sect2.para: Use these instructions if there is no existing Linux system on your machine, or if you want to replace an existing Linux system.
sect2.remark: missing from fate #305034: iso image installation into a virtualized environment (m)

step.para: Insert the &productname; DVD into the drive, then reboot the computer to start the installation program. On machines with a traditional BIOS you will see the graphical boot screen shown below. On machines equipped with UEFI, a non-graphical boot screen is used. Secure boot on UEFI machines is supported.
Use F2 to change the language for the installer. A corresponding keyboard layout is chosen automatically. Change the video resolution for the installer with F3. See or for more information.
Select Installation on the boot screen, then press Enter. This boots the system and loads the &productname; installer.
Language and the Keyboard Layout are initialized with the language settings you have chosen on the boot screen. Change them here, if necessary.

Read the License Agreement. It is presented in the language you have chosen on the boot screen. License Translations are available. You need to accept the agreement by checking I Agree to the License Terms in order to install &productname;. Proceed with Next.

tip.title: Release Notes
tip.para:
The Release Notes can be viewed from any screen during the installation process by selecting Release Notes.

step.para: After a system analysis (where the installer probes for storage devices and tries to find other installed systems on your machine) you can register your system at the SUSE Customer Center (SCC). Enter the e-mail address associated with your SCC account and the registration code for &productname;. A successful registration is a prerequisite for getting product updates and being entitled for technical support. Proceed with Next.

Check Include add-on Products from Separate Media to include add-on products during the installation. An add-on product can include extensions, third-party products and drivers or additional software for your system.

tip.title: Installing Product Patches and Drivers during the Installation
tip.para: In case your organization provides the update channel for SUSE Linux Enterprise Server via an SMT server, it is possible to specify this channel as an add-on product by entering its HTTP address. As a consequence, the system will be installed with the most current packages without having to apply the updates at the end of the installation.

You can also add driver update repositories via the Add-On Products dialog. Driver updates for SUSE Linux Enterprise are provided at . These drivers have been created via the Partner Linux Driver Program.

step.para: Proceed with Next to choose the installation source for the add-on product. It can be installed either from a local source (CD, DVD, or directory) or from a network source (HTTP, FTP, NFS, CIFS,...). A network source can only be used when the network interface has been successfully configured via DHCP when the installation system started, or when having provided the networking data manually at the boot prompt (see for details).

Check Download Repository Description Files to download the files describing the repository now. If unchecked, they will be downloaded once the installation starts. Proceed with Next and insert a media if required. Depending on the product's content it may be necessary to accept additional license agreements. Proceed with Next.
Review and, if necessary, change the partition setup proposed by the system. You have the following options:

listitem.para: lets you change options of the proposed settings, but not the suggested partition layout itself
select a disk to which to apply the proposal
lets you import a partitioning scheme from a previous installation found on the hard disk(s)
opens the Expert Partitioner described in

step.para: To accept the proposed setup without any changes, choose Next to proceed.

Select the clock and time zone to use in your system. To manually adjust the time or to configure an NTP server for time synchronization, choose Other Settings. See for detailed information. Proceed with Next.
To create a local user by typing the first and last name in the Userâ€™s Full Name field, the login name in the Username field, and the password in the Password field.

the password should be at least eight characters long and should contain both uppercase and lowercase letters and numbers. The maximum length for passwords is 72 characters, and passwords are case-sensitive.

For security reasons it is also strongly recommended not to enable the Automatic Login. You should also not Use this Password for the System Administrator but rather provide a separate &rootuser; password in the next installation step. Mails generated by the system are delivered to the user &rootuser; by default. Check Receive System Mail if you would rather get them as the user you just created.
Selecting Change gets you to the expert options explained at . Proceed with Next.
Type a password for the system administrator account (called the &rootuser; user).
You should never forget the &rootuser; password! After you entered it here, the password cannot be retrieved. See for more information. Proceed with Next.

Use the Installation Settings screen to review and—if necessary—change a number of proposed installation settings. The current configuration is listed for each setting. To change it, click the headline. Some settings, such as firewall or SSH can directly be changed by clicking on the respective links.

tip.title: Default Installation
tip.para: Changes you can make here, can also be made later at any time from the installed system. However, if you need remote access directly after the installation, you should adjust the Firewall and SSH settings according to your need.

listitem.para: The default scope of software includes the base system and X Window with the GNOME desktop. Clicking Software opens the Software Selection and System Tasks screen, where you can change the software selection by selecting or deselecting patterns. Each pattern contains a number of software packages needed for specific functions (e.g. Web and LAMP server or a print server). For a more detailed selection based on software packages to install, select Details to switch to the &yast; Software Manager. See for more information.
This section shows the bootloader configuration. Changing the defaults is only recommended if really needed. Refer to for details.
By default, the Firewall is enabled with the active network interface configured for the external zone. See for configuration details.
The SSH service is disabled by default, it's port (22) is closed. Therefore login in from remote is not possible by default. Click enable and open to toggle these settings.

Kdump saves the memory image (core dump) to the file system in case the Kernel crashes. This enables you to find the cause of the crash by debugging the dump file. Kdump is preconfigured and enabled by default. See for more information.
By default, the system boots into the graphical target, with network, multiuser and display manager support. Switch to multi-user if you do not need to login via display manager.
View detailed hardware information by clicking System. In the resulting screen you can also change Kernel Settings—see FIXME for more information.

step.para: Once you have finalized the system configuration on the Installation Settings screen, click Install. Depending on your software selection you may have to agree to license agreements before the installation confirmation screen pops up. Up to this point no changes have been made to your system. Once you click Install again, the installation process starts.
During the installation, the progress is shown in detail on the Perform Installation screen.

After the installation routine has finished, the computer is rebooted into the installed system. Login and start &yast; to fine-tune the system. If you are not using a graphical desktop or working from remote, refer to for information on using &yast; from a terminal.
